Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Renewables: Fundamental allometric scalings for distribution networks with renewables

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the study of many large systems that evolve through choices made by many individuals over time, mathematical relationships have found to appear that are very similar even in different applications. These relationships are often in the form of so-called scaling laws, giving an algebraic relationship between quantities that involves an exponent of one of the quantities that may measure the size of the system. As the system size grows, another system measure will change based on the scaling law. Such phenomena can be viewed as allometric scalings, since allometry has to do with the relationship between growth of parts of an organism and the growth of the organism itself. This project will study scaling laws in electric power distribution networks, and seek to determine whether such laws could be used to design more reliable power distribution systems. The design variables that could be considered include system parameters such as cable properties and structural aspects of the overall distribution network.

Allometric scalings are nonlinear, power-law relationships that govern system parameters and performance. Inspired by the remarkable allometric scalings in biology, initial work by the PI in collaboration with a colleague at Oxford University has resulted in evidence of allometric scaling in observed data for blackouts in distribution networks. Moreover, the initial work suggests physics and engineering design principles that could explain these scalings and relate distribution network parameters to its reliability in terms of the possibility that customers will be disconnected from the grid. Distribution networks must be redesigned and upgraded to accommodate renewable sources and new loads. The project seeks to establish and apply the new scaling theory to help ensure the reliability of the redesigned distribution networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electric power distribution grids are the wires connecting substations to houses and businesses. Most blackouts involve disruption of the distribution grid. The project investigated patterns in the reliability of distribution grids. In particular, the project discovered a scaling relation in how the number of customers disconnected relates to blackout frequency.  Blackouts with more customers disconnected are less frequent and the scaling relation describes how much less frequent they are. An example of a scaling relation is that when the number of customers disconnected doubles, the frequency of that size of blackout is halved. Electrical utility data from the UK and USA were processed and analyzed to show these scalings. Understanding these scalings could help engineers to design and  maintain a more reliable distribution grid, even as the distribution grid changes to accomodate solar power and electric vehicles. Similar scalings are also known in biological networks such as the blood supply to organs. Inspired by these ideas in biology, the project tried to explain the scalings in the distribution grid. Many factors affect the scaling, such as how the distribution grid is laid out (as shown in the figure), where the customers are, the reliability of the wires, and the engineering of the devices that disconnect parts of the grid when there is a short circuit (a high voltage version of an electrical breaker in a house). The project aimed to explain the scalings by processing the data available from the electric utility, but found that data was satisfactory for only some of the factors involved, and this prevented the various ideas for the scalings to be fully analyzed and tested. That is, the project discovered the scaling relation and processed electrical utility data into useful datasets, but the knowledge gained so far did not satisfactorily explain the scaling. To obtain and process the UK distribution grid data, the project collaborated with researchers from the Environmental Change Institute at the University of Oxford in England. The project also developed course materials for an undergraduate course in electrical distribution networks and shared these materials with other universities.
